jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

ECC24A7486174A5BA205C14FD73FB221.description: Research a famous playwright or dramatic work.

B3C14E3BB3A245419C453AEEA8FD427F.description: Explore a variety of theatrical works that were performed during the Renaissance

E02EE558805D4F7687BC221A404B12BD.description: Discuss how theatre evolved throughout the Renaissance in Europe and England

4CF4D087765C4DEAA7B584DE8414D7DF.description: Investigate traditions or stories from Canadian communities as an inspiration for creating dramatizations

DA6B62DCFB724D40ACF73BC381457742.description: Observe dramatic works from modern-day professional theatre companies

E16FAF893CC843AD8F4F01743505498F.description: Explore the narrative of a heroic epic as an inspiration for creating dramatizations

76184487AA5E454FAD0B642BA2AF6831.description: Drama went through a significant change during the Renaissance and the Protestant Reformation

09496A1F9FFB4FA0BC1B15CF78B57FA0.description: Drama in colonial Canada was reflective of the changes that occurred in Europe at the same time

3D9CF8AB0AC7427EA2C0844D853B6C4D.description: Drama has changed over time as communities and cultures have evolved.

C4506CC3DA554A6FA460BBF03BCB0749.description: In 1642, many theatres and playhouses were shut down or burned down because some religious groups believed that drama was an inappropriate art form.

D63F727EA2ED435C96F4586094FACEE6.description: Famous playwrights who emerged and influenced drama during the Renaissance include Shakespeare (1564-1616), an English playwright, poet, and actor considered one of the greatest writers of the English language Jean-Baptiste Poquelin (1622- 1673), a French playwright, actor, and poet known by the stage name Moliere and considered one of the greatest writers of the French language

4BCA5542F85646A5B42EB269D81EDC8E.description: During the Renaissance in England, theatres became public venues where all social classes could come together and enjoy performances.

099B75076E8842C9978F31E28D693596.description: The thrust stage was developed during the Elizabethan period to bring the action closer to the common people, while the upper class sat in elevated boxes, as seen in Shakespeare's Globe Theatre

8F81A65CFD8E4038A8E5251174D5A3DB.description: Elizabethan theatre took place primarily outdoors in theatres, including the courtyards of inns The Rose Theatre The Curtain The Globe Theatre

10F91CA4C9BC4AE5BE996E432657EDC4.description: Elizabethan theatre performances were less informed by classical Roman influence and more informed by what was popular with British audiences

E1DC6298FC90423594B1A218EAC02FD0.description: The term Elizabethan emerged from the English Renaissance to reflect the style of performance that was popular during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I (1558-1603)

AAD81C4840F64C69A4FC086E6B96FCAC.description:
In 1517, the Protestant Reformation influenced traditional Renaissance views on arts and theatre, which included plays that gave actors more work with less emphasis on
religion

B671D84FC76E4168ACE24D7BDD5DF118.description: Commedia dell-arte influenced the development of modern-day musical theatre, opera, and improvisational comedy.

C368EF83959E44828922C65799953579.description: Commedia dell-arte was developed as a form of clowning in Italy during the Renaissance and used stock characters to develop improvisational and scripted scenes.

086B543F406A43F381A830172DDEF257.description: The Teatro Olimpico is a Palladian theatre that still exists in Vincenza, Italy, today

ECC4F2010A384F0C9E2F857340206C90.description: Before the construction of the Palladian theatre, dramatizations were performed on simple outdoor stages with only curtains for a backdrop.

642C5DDBAACD457FAAD2BEEC5DD855C6.description: The construction of Palladian theatres allowed for more elaborate scenes and sets to be used and influenced modern-day theatres

962D5E93FE5144B0B8F911A1F5DE5790.description: Palladian theatres were designed by the architect Palladio, and were the first indoor theatres to exist during the Renaissance

4A99AEF0C0AF41E2AEB51ED3499BC576.description: Mystery plays were dramatizations based on bible stories that were commonly performed at church or at celebrations such as religious festivals

EA7896AC99D748BF8C37E560D9E8C8A6.description: Plays about morality during the European Renaissance evolved out of mystery plays from the Middle Ages.

D4B063F71B65469B820D7B4C6B3F203D.description: The Renaissance era was about all people bettering themselves through education, literature, science, and the arts

9F1A9A119A7D4FB3B6CFB79D07F700E8.description: Stories told through drama in Canadian communities could be linked to a person's place of origin

98A8424700554357AD77ED2A6785B72B.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit storytelling and languages were banned by Canadian government policies in colonial Canada.

AE2C27DD79974D4D8801CA3377D60406.description: Non-professional theatre in colonial Canada influenced modern Francophone professional theatre companies, including Cirque du Soleil (Quebec) TheatreÂ  Pic (Alberta)

15F91B55727348568671B4E2C8F677B9.description: Non-professional (amateur) drama evolved into a professional theatrical art form in colonial Canada.

E9C56A10010744ABBD98563207F811B1.description: As more people immigrated to Canada from various parts of the world, they brought with them the dramatic traditions and cultures of their homelands

2D3F9CE681B94B97B26358D551C48950.description: Professional actors began to arrive in colonial Canada from Europe and the Thirteen Colonies during the great migration (1815-1850)

E1F5F759F54E4C4D9FB5424FF0CEA2B1.description: Heroic epic was used to retell the story of the Battle of the Plains of Abraham

A75206A3ECE04C35B4CF0F24C8354E3F.description: Heroic epics originated in ancient Greece and continue to be used in drama today

645E50A6E8284FD68C4F005E1218E8DA.description: An epic is a long, narrative poem that reflects the heroic actions of a person or group of people in a certain time and place

BFACF4892C184AAFBC20847C276F717C.description: Literary styles such as heroic epic were reflected in the drama and theatre of colonial Canada

951E0521D4AC4BC199FD7551B2B04848.description: European and French playwrights inspired the subject matter of theatre in colonial Canada.

15D863EF21104A38AF0C47DF5AB47CDC.description: Students investigate how changes in past societies have influenced the creation and sharing of drama.

82B92326810B4FF99DA2DB702417DA37.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

750CA713F27D4F56A647CAA31A757C46.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in drama

A53F9EB41EB64F0DA359AB8E80ABB9F5.description: Demonstrate how to follow staging cues when clarifying positions and movement of performers in a narrative

90BD78CB4E3348C090B8F789F4B4B76A.description: Experiment with the possibilities of the voice and the body in communication of a narrative

DFB77D9BF0644B6291EF601953F4E895.description: Describe how feedback about the narrative was incorporated.

DCF9CF811BC4404687576ABB281B0CE3.description: Express a character's status through role play

99C9DD507FA9498EB00ED77B91BC9B5C.description: Make artistic choices in the creation of a narrative

C6D28250765641419AFD96030BB04513.description: Explore narratives in First Nations, Metis, or Inuit storytelling

6FBCDF40CF8A47DE8ECC64E89602E958.description: Perform invented or scripted dramas based on a narrative

6B9AE0926AB54AC0A2E5E2EE3FB460AD.description: Choose a topic to communicate through a narrative

63D73DA120034526B089B9572DAE0702.description: Explore how the use of technical elements can enhance the structure of a narrative

0634190616ED42BF9448B9DCEE733696.description: Experiment with improvisation as a way to structure a narrative

4B2EC4EAABB9430EA49E3604EAF493E3.description: Create a plan for structuring a narrative

7204A3A59CBB4E45B363E253BF18ADDE.description: A narrative may be perceived by an audience in a way that differs from what the performer intended

7D4880A975E9483CAAD846F3066E8BEF.description: A narrative can take an audience on a journey by entertaining and persuading

8ADF3732E7A8488E95B0057782B53F7B.description: The exploration of a culture's narrative through drama can help the viewer to build cultural understanding

1259150C51714ABF934561F0CA8CA9C4.description: A narrative can communicate knowledge and understandings about the world

81CBE9080DF047E6B11F59CF8897434F.description: A narrative can be structured to describe the past, the present, or the future

37D20610819D4981B03BB6BC576A7D5A.description: Audience participation can enhance how a narrative is communicated in drama.

B926700E60C94059AED83C3C4EA397AE.description: Feedback from an audience can influence future performances

CC9732E8A0E04292A2AF21822487D945.description: Status can change depending on how the body and voice is used

5B764787445342A3905DA525A40E0125.description: Status is the level of importance or power that a character holds in relation to other characters

DDC1AD04333A41D4A168FEFB3D83C6E0.description: A character's status or feelings can be communicated and enhanced through narrative

D117C5163C0341F984C5CC95434821D5.description: Artistic choices can revise and re imagine how a narrative is expressed and can include the use of voice body dramatic forms technical elements staging

661974174DDD4F6CAC8DD055105DE0A8.description: Narrative in First Nations, Metis, and Inuit storytelling can originate from the land and include the wind water soil animals plants

F48EAE7FF5744258A5A6397EED460DE5.description: Narrative can be expressed in First Nations, Metis, and Inuit stories and can be witnessed through the spirit or life of the storyteller

1CEEC73EC26E490397F03DD3479BBF73.description: A narrative is represented in diverse ways across cultures

183BE178C0FF4F63BFB7A97E127612A8.description: There are universal themes that can occur in narratives, including redemption survival quest

99F4CB6FE5724D5B916732FC44292CF9.description: A narrative can be based on stories, legends, myths, and poetry fictional or non-fictional events characters individuals or communities historical or cultural events

FC9BA280E4A74C7D90F8E780F394E3FF.description: Narrative can be planned or improvised.

D41141FFC28046DB81F55B824584AE33.description: Dramatic forms can be used to structure how a narrative is told

6C9F297361844F8B8B14EBE3C1B9A193.description: Narrative can be represented individually or collectively.

C60B31CD97D04829BCA741307C98048C.description: Technical elements applied to staging can enhance how a narrative is represented

86169573B59D49DE9A47B03033838DB5.description: Staging considerations can influence representation of a narrative

5671923295FE4CB6A6011E42AAD3B004.description: Parts of a narrative may be excluded, leaving the audience to assume what happened before and after the narrative was presented

8C8683899B2E487A910F4956D4D0476F.description: Dramatic tension in a narrative can build suspense and can give the audience something to anticipate

FB24BED2462642CAB70A8CC5AE61ADCC.description: The structure of a narrative can include a beginning, a problem, and a resolution.

6B9E85F04807428DB1CB3B27D61DA726.description: Students represent narratives based on a variety of inspirations and through the application of artistic choices

7F7F6A2CAC8C445C9F65B011DAFF5D31.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

BC5D2776F62649FA84A636DC4154CCC1.description: Discuss the effectiveness of technical elements used in a dramatization

64323911D3A941B99E4E83B60AD84724.description: Explore the effects that technical elements have in a dramatization.

6077BB18BD3D422185688B54897C9D1C.description: Explore the effects that body positions can have on dramatic expression

96A11DF8439D48A58F08300C42713EBE.description: Explore how blocking can contribute to presentations in drama

8A0714B793364EE6865435B5E67A6302.description: Implement changes to a particular area to create a performance space

0D155A5E2F70447AAB6F9513E568A9E1.description: Identify various ways an audience can participate in a drama

97FF511C3C474344BC6B53152026B720.description: Explore how tension in the body and breath can influence vocal quality

D459E60D466E4726B8DFB360497D0FAC.description: Discuss how proper body and vocal warm-ups can contribute to dramatic expression.

E4C803ED9B4A4B6FB5B352E33F9F4904.description: Participate in various ways to warm up the body and voice

DA83F05DE6CC445494DCEC675DDE414F.description: Explore how vocal release is dependent on body and breath

F689D766FC9D4283BD2BE5F21ACE6885.description: Experiment with how the voice can shape the development of a character or situation

C7D5C6BE1046442D8974A352AE04B3D5.description: Explore the use of articulators in adjusting vocal sounds.

224563CDBBB34345911BE9623AD7A878.description: Differentiate between stereotypes and authentic character.

5C33B41CC27D47B9A756F95259165F1D.description: Experiment with how the voice can create a variety of sounds.

AB38F3986BE14C6BAD3E589FB154C7CF.description: Staging includes technical elements that can enhance a dramatization

92D51CC03988468B8B66E77BA0ADF15B.description: Staging reflects the relationship between the audience and performer(s) within a performance space

3C2A0F914DC64A1C90A0337432A365CD.description: Staging supports expression in dramatic performances

80A907B80CD4454BA069C03E32152321.description: Any space can be transformed into a performance space

534CF036F54440CD9B96C6B5493FA80F.description: The voice functions optimally when warmed up, exercised, and relaxed.

8E42B0D2CF7B4B0FA863E6100923C050.description: The voice is released from the body with an appropriate amount of breath for the space, idea, and feeling

CDA8D06254C14D1B909395B27F41B3C4.description: The voice conveys a performer's intention in the way that it is used

B87EA0FF553F4D1699229F35989ED5A4.description: The voice has a natural and distinguishable tone that can represent the uniqueness of an individual

C72181BCEF054AEABF08714A04BE7213.description: The voice is an expressive instrument that is capable of producing and reproducing sound

5914BFAB3B5E4C45AB928F58B43F9F57.description: Technical elements can influence an audience's experience of a dramatization

DE2E6CAD579D4542AF65F5320A25A67A.description: Technical elements can be added to a performance to clarify ideas for an audience, and can include costumes props sounds sets lighting

A836C0F3B8114F60887616AD79575A26.description: Staging can enhance a dramatization through the use of movement or stillness light or dark sound or silence

A8C6D484E381443D8FE23857EC892DA5.description: Audiences may engage in a performance in a variety of ways, including singing using props verbally answering questions from the performer(s) suggesting ideas

919A01A20197472494C7F4D75FB079A9.description: A dramatization may include the audience as a participant in the performance

4011CFE5021D42F0980C451F98ACC559.description: Not all dramatic forms can be staged in the same way

A72202C83B07435CAE55BE20B7B5CB26.description: Body positions on stage can include full front, profile, and full back

79D38C265A4D4490A75D687BF7AEF3C1.description: Blocking is a performer's movement and positioning on stage that can influence expression

62AE95CD55FC484090AC8D97036DA5BF.description: Staging considerations include optimal audibility and visibility for an audience

DE943374801B4B9C95D968B6D051848D.description: Staging includes the movement of actors and objects in a performance space

ED4C2CC90B2D48ECBBABD73C08947ED5.description: Tension in the body and breath affects how the voice expresses thought and feeling.

EDF245049D284B359CC3FAF4B303CCF0.description: Vocal warm-ups for drama can include exercises for breath control pitch variation projection articulation

324C375E70704BDA91826604A66A1B2B.description: Physical warm-ups for drama can include stretching extensions breath exercises cardiovascular exercise

316DB0CCD82C4340A9B3A9C21BE13E7B.description: Stage whispers require an excess release of breath to project the voice effectively.

225D166D8BBF4CF09C860CD75E800752.description: The amount of breath used in vocal production will vary according to the performance space.

F5D06AA9513840F69B8AA08BEB30D180.description: The voice can represent the perspective of the character

AB213DDE0A274ADFB97408CDD750298D.description: The voice can be used to represent thoughts feelings experiences imagination personal attributes

3F225F5D148844649E8A44B7570BD5B6.description: The voice is what is heard, felt, and imagined by an audience.

0BC28CFE9197410982FC8CEE07588258.description: The articulators contribute to producing clear sounds and words and can be developed through vocal exercises, including tongue twisters

01BBD9A23D0248A6B939BD628374007E.description: Articulators are vocal organs in the body that influence sound and can include the lips teeth tongue hard pallet soft pallet

6E588EDAEA5E47D4964AEEDCBA3E55BD.description: An authentic character is an accurate and genuine representation of a person

51A27EAA1B5C4A28A45524D1C8EBA2AC.description: Stereotypes in drama are collections of personality traits or generalizations of what a character sounds like or looks like.

89F1849F238143F5B0B78F32FEAC04F5.description: The voice and the body can reflect stereotypes and characters in drama

532FEBA59E3C439181F90AA324D771A6.description: Production of the voice includes vocal pitch energy tone volume projection articulation phrasing pace

21CE4838FFF84420A627C5239D82FB4E.description: Tone of voice includes volume emphasis accent intonation

58A534845B5A4849A9DC5F36E6A77D0F.description: Students investigate voice and staging as a means of expression in drama.

8124043CC5FA4C58BF9F21341B2CC62B.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
